cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
when did the first movie of harry potter come out
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process: 
To determine when the first Harry Potter movie was released, I need to recall the title of the first film in the series. The first book, "Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone" (also known as "Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone" in the U.S.), was published in 1997. The film adaptation was produced after the book's success. I remember that the movie was released in the early 2000s. Specifically, it was released in November, which is a common time for major films to debut.

Answer: The first movie of Harry Potter, "Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone," was released on November 16, 2001.

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
when did the first movie of harry potter come out
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['The film was released on 31 May 2004 in the United Kingdom and on 4 June 2004 in North America, as the first "Harry Potter" film released into IMAX theatres and to be using IMAX Technology. The film was nominated for two Academy Awards, Best Original Music Score and Best Visual Effects at the 77th Academy Awards in 2004.\n', 'The first trailer was released on YouTube in April 2010 and the premier was viewed by an audience of 1200 at the Europahalle theater in Trier. The film opened on 21 October 2010 at the Broadway Theater (also in Trier), becoming 7000 viewers in the first three weeks. At the time, no film in the five years preceding had sold more tickets at that theater, to include Harry Potter (film series). With an initial shipment of 5,000, the DVD was released on 9 December 2010 and by the end of January 2011 had sold 16,000 of the total 23,000 produced.\n', 'In October 1998, Warner Bros. purchased the film rights to the first two novels for a seven-figure sum. A film adaptation of "Harry Potter and the Philosopher\'s Stone" was released on 16 November 2001, and "Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets" on 15 November 2002. Both films were directed by Chris Columbus. The film version of "Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban" was released on 4 June 2004, directed by Alfonso Cuarón. The fourth film, "Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire", was directed by Mike Newell, and released on 18 November 2005. The film of "Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix" was released on 11 July 2007. David Yates directed, and Michael Goldenberg wrote the screenplay, having taken over the position from Steve Kloves. "Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince" was released on 15 July 2009. David Yates directed again, and Kloves returned to write the script. Warner Bros. filmed the final instalment of the series, "Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows", in two segments, with part one being released on 19 November 2010 and part two being released on 15 July 2011. Yates directed both films.\n', 'The rights for the first four novels in the series were sold to Warner Bros. for £1,000,000 by J.K. Rowling. After the release of the fourth book in July 2000, the first film, "Harry Potter and the Philosopher\'s Stone", was released on 16 November 2001. In its opening weekend, the film grossed $90 million in the United States alone, which set a record opening worldwide. The succeeding three motion picture adaptations followed suit in financial success, while garnering positive reviews from fans and critics. The fifth film, "Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix", was released by Warner Bros. on 11 July 2007 in English-speaking countries, except for the UK and Ireland, which released the movie on 12 July. The sixth, "Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince", was released on 15 July 2009 to critical acclaim and finished its theatrical run ranked as the number two grossing film of 2009 on the worldwide charts.\n', 'In the late 1990s, Warner obtained rights to the "Harry Potter" novels and released feature film adaptations of the first in 2001. Subsequently, they released the second film in 2002, the third in June 2004, the fourth in November 2005, the fifth in July 2007, and the sixth in July 2009. The seventh (and at that time, final) book was released as two movies; Deathly Hallows\xa0— Part 1 in November 2010 and Deathly Hallows\xa0— Part 2 in July 2011.\n', 'Although the original film release date was June 8, 2012, in January 2011 Disney moved the release date to March 9, 2012. A teaser trailer for the film premiered on July 14, 2011 and was shown in 3D and 2D with showings of "Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows – Part 2"; the official trailer premiered on November 30, 2011. On February 5, 2012 an extended commercial promoting the movie aired during the Super Bowl, and before the day of the game, Andrew Stanton, a Massachusetts native, held a special screening of the film for both the team members and families of the New England Patriots and New York Giants.\n', 'The book was published in the United Kingdom by Bloomsbury and in the United States by Scholastic; in both countries the release date was 8 July 2000, the first time a book in the series was published in both countries at the same time. The novel won a Hugo Award, the only "Harry Potter" novel to do so, in 2001. The book was adapted into a film, which was released worldwide on 18 November 2005, and a video game by Electronic Arts.\n', 'The first trailer was released on December 23, 2013 and attached theatrically with "Saving Mr. Banks". Disney heavily promoted the film through its ESPN division, with Bill Simmons being credited an executive producer on the film. The film was fully screened at CinemaCon in March 2014, wherein Walt Disney Studios chairman Alan Horn claimed that it was the highest-tested film during his tenure at either Disney or Warner Bros., including the first "Harry Potter" film. The film held its world premiere at the El Capitan Theatre on May 6, 2014.\n', 'Harold "Harry" Potts, played by Russell Dixon, made his first screen appearance on 26 October 1992.\n', 'In August 2003, British film director Mike Newell was chosen to direct the film after "Prisoner of Azkaban" director Alfonso Cuarón announced that he would not direct the sequel. Heyman returned to produce, and Kloves again wrote the screenplay. Principal photography began on 4 May 2004. Scenes involving the film\'s principal actors began shooting on 25 June 2004 at England\'s Leavesden Film Studios. "Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire" premiered on 6 November 2005 in London, and was released in the United Kingdom and the United States on 18 November. "Goblet of Fire" was the first film in the series to receive a PG-13 rating by the Motion Picture Association of America (MPAA) for "sequences of fantasy violence and frightening images," M by the Australian Classification Board (ACB), and a 12A by the British Board of Film Classification (BBFC) for its dark themes, fantasy violence, threat and frightening images.\n']

Task Description:

which can provide the model with relevant background and unknown knowledge and concepts, 
helping it better understand the question. and analyze the role of these contents.

To answer the question about when the first Harry Potter movie was released, we can extract and analyze relevant content from the provided passages. The key information is as follows:

1. **Release Date of the First Film**: The first film, "Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone," was released on **16 November 2001**. This is a crucial piece of information that directly answers the question.

2. **Context of the Film Series**: The passages provide context about the Harry Potter film series, including the release dates of subsequent films:
   - "Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets" on **15 November 2002**.
   - "Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban" on **4 June 2004**.
   - "Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire" on **18 November 2005**.
   - "Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix" on **11 July 2007**.
   - "Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince" on **15 July 2009**.
   - "Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows" was released in two parts: Part 1 on **19 November 2010** and Part 2 on **15 July 2011**.

3. **Background on Film Rights**: The passages mention that Warner Bros. purchased the film rights to the first two novels in **October 1998** for a significant sum, which illustrates the commercial potential of the Harry Potter franchise and the interest it generated even before the first film was released.

4. **Cultural Impact**: The first film grossed **$90 million** in its opening weekend in the United States, setting a record at the time. This information highlights the film's immediate financial success and cultural impact, indicating its significance in the film industry.

5. **Director Information**: The first two films were directed by **Chris Columbus**, which provides insight into the creative direction of the initial adaptations.

### Analysis of the Role of These Contents:

- **Direct Answer**: The most critical piece of information is the release date of the first film, which directly answers the question posed.

- **Contextual Understanding**: The additional details about subsequent films and the background of the film rights help to contextualize the significance of the first film within the broader Harry Potter franchise. This context can enhance understanding of the series' evolution and its impact on popular culture.

- **Cultural Significance**: The financial success of the first film underscores its importance not just as a film but as a cultural phenomenon, which may be relevant for understanding why the series remains popular.

- **Creative Contributions**: Knowing who directed the films can provide insight into the style and approach taken in the adaptations, which may be relevant for discussions about the films' reception and legacy.

In summary, while the direct answer to the question is straightforward, the surrounding context enriches the understanding of the Harry Potter film series and its significance in the film industry and popular culture.

The first book, "Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone" (known as "Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone" in the U.S.), was published in 1997, which set the stage for the film adaptation due to the book's immense popularity. 

The film adaptation was produced after the book's success, and I recall that it was released in the early 2000s. Specifically, it premiered in November, a common time for major films to debut, especially those aimed at family audiences during the holiday season.

From the retrieved knowledge, I can confirm that the first film, "Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone," was released on **16 November 2001**. The first movie of Harry Potter, "Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone," was released on November 16, 2001.

**Expert Discussion on the Release of the First Harry Potter Movie**

**Expert 1: Film Historian**
The first Harry Potter film, "Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone," was released on 16 November 2001. This film marked the beginning of a significant cinematic franchise that adapted J.K. Rowling's beloved novels. The release date is crucial as it set the stage for the subsequent films, which followed a yearly or biennial release pattern.

**Expert 2: Cultural Analyst**
I agree with the film historian regarding the release date. However, it's important to note the cultural impact of the film's release. The film not only brought the story to a wider audience but also influenced the perception of fantasy films in mainstream cinema. The success of the first film paved the way for adaptations of other fantasy novels, which had previously struggled to find a foothold in Hollywood.

**Expert 3: Box Office Analyst**
From a financial perspective, the opening weekend gross of $90 million in the United States alone was unprecedented at the time. This financial success was a clear indicator of the film's popularity and the effective marketing strategies employed by Warner Bros. The film's performance set a benchmark for future adaptations and established a lucrative franchise model.

**Expert 4: Literary Scholar**
While the film's release date and box office success are important, we must also consider the adaptation process. The film was directed by Chris Columbus, who made significant choices in how to translate the source material to screen. This adaptation process has been a topic of much debate among fans and scholars, particularly regarding fidelity to the original text and the portrayal of key characters and themes.

**Expert 5: Technology and Film Expert**
Additionally, it's worth mentioning the technological advancements that accompanied the release of the Harry Potter films. The use of special effects and CGI in "Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone" was groundbreaking for its time and contributed to the film's immersive experience. This aspect is often overlooked when discussing the film's impact.

**Points of Agreement and Disagreement:**
All experts agree on the significance of the release date—16 November 2001—as a pivotal moment in film history. They also concur on the film's cultural and financial impact. However, there is some disagreement regarding the focus of the discussion. While some experts emphasize box office performance and cultural influence, others highlight the adaptation process and technological advancements.

**Synthesis of Insights:**
The discussion reveals that the release of "Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone" was not just a milestone in cinema but a multifaceted event that influenced various domains, including culture, finance, and technology. The film's success established a new paradigm for fantasy adaptations, showcasing the importance of effective marketing, technological innovation, and thoughtful adaptation of beloved literary works. 

In conclusion, the first Harry Potter film's release date is a foundational fact, but its implications extend far beyond that. The collaborative insights from the experts illustrate how this single event can be analyzed from multiple perspectives, enriching our understanding of its significance in both film history and popular culture.

The seventh (and at that time, final) book was released as two movies; Deathly Hallows\xa0— Part 1 in November 2010 and Deathly Hallows\xa0— Part 2 in July 2011.
', 'Although the original film release date was June 8, 2012, in January 2011 Disney moved the release date to March 9, 2012. A teaser trailer for the film premiered on July 14, 2011 and was shown in 3D and 2D with showings of "Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows – Part 2"; the official trailer premiered on November 30, 2011. On February 5, 2012 an extended commercial promoting the movie aired during the Super Bowl, and before the day of the game, Andrew Stanton, a Massachusetts native, held a special screening of the film for both the team members and families of the New England Patriots and New York Giants.
', 'The book was published in the United Kingdom by Bloomsbury and in the United States by Scholastic; in both countries the release date was 8 July 2000, the first time a book in the series was published in both countries at the same time. The novel won a Hugo Award, the only "Harry Potter" novel to do so, in 2001. The book was adapted into a film, which was released worldwide on 18 November 2005, and a video game by Electronic Arts.
', 'The first trailer was released on December 23, 2013 and attached theatrically with "Saving Mr. Banks". Disney heavily promoted the film through its ESPN division, with Bill Simmons being credited an executive producer on the film. The film was fully screened at CinemaCon in March 2014, wherein Walt Disney Studios chairman Alan Horn claimed that it was the highest-tested film during his tenure at either Disney or Warner Bros., including the first "Harry Potter" film. The film held its world premiere at the El Capitan Theatre on May 6, 2014.
', 'Harold "Harry" Potts, played by Russell Dixon, made his first screen appearance on 26 October 1992.
', 'In August 2003, British film director Mike Newell was chosen to direct the film after "Prisoner of Azkaban" director Alfonso Cuarón announced that he would not direct the sequel. Heyman returned to produce, and Kloves again wrote the screenplay. Principal photography began on 4 May 2004. Scenes involving the film's principal actors began shooting on 25 June 2004 at England's Leavesden Film Studios. "Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire" premiered on 6 November 2005 in London, and was released in the United Kingdom and the United States on 18 November. "Goblet of Fire" was the first film in the series to receive a PG-13 rating by the Motion Picture Association of America (MPAA) for "sequences of fantasy violence and frightening images," M by the Australian Classification Board (ACB), and a 12A by the British Board of Film Classification (BBFC) for its dark themes, fantasy violence, threat and frightening images.
']

Task Description:

consolidate these contents, and analyze how the selected information may impact the improvement of the model's causal reasoning and logical inference capabilities.

To answer the question of when the first Harry Potter movie was released, we can extract relevant information from the provided passages. The key details are as follows:

1. **Release Date of the First Film**: The first film, "Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone," was released on **16 November 2001**.

2. **Context of the Film's Production**: Warner Bros. purchased the film rights to the first two novels in October 1998, and the film adaptation was released after the fourth book was published in July 2000.

3. **Success of the Film**: The film grossed $90 million in its opening weekend in the United States, setting a record for worldwide openings at that time.

4. **Subsequent Releases**: The passages also mention the release dates of the subsequent films, which can help establish a timeline for the series.

### Consolidation of Information:
The first Harry Potter film was released on **16 November 2001**, following the acquisition of film rights by Warner Bros. in 1998. The film was a significant commercial success, grossing $90 million in its opening weekend.

### Analysis of Impact on Causal Reasoning and Logical Inference:
1. **Temporal Sequencing**: The information establishes a clear timeline of events—acquisition of rights, publication of the fourth book, and the subsequent release of the film. This helps the model understand cause-and-effect relationships, such as how the publication of the book led to the film's production.

2. **Understanding Success Metrics**: The mention of the film's financial success provides a basis for analyzing factors that contribute to a film's success, such as marketing, audience anticipation, and critical reception. This can enhance the model's ability to infer why certain films perform better than others.

3. **Contextual Relationships**: The passages provide context about the film industry during the time of the Harry Potter releases, which can help the model understand broader trends in filmmaking and audience behavior. This contextual knowledge is crucial for making logical inferences about future film releases and their potential success.

4. **Causal Links**: By understanding the relationship between the book's popularity and the film's success, the model can better infer how adaptations from literature to film can impact audience engagement and box office performance.

In summary, the extracted information not only answers the specific question about the release date of the first Harry Potter film but also enriches the model's understanding of causal relationships and logical inference in the context of film production and success. This can lead to improved reasoning capabilities in similar contexts.

question:
when did the first movie of harry potter come out
answer:
Reasoning process: 
To determine when the first Harry Potter movie was released, I need to recall the title of the first film in the series. The first book, "Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone" (also known as "Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone" in the U.S.), was published in 1997. The film adaptation was produced after the book's success. I remember that the movie was released in the early 2000s. Specifically, it was released in November, which is a common time for major films to debut.

Answer: The first movie of Harry Potter, "Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone," was released on November 16, 2001.

To determine when the first Harry Potter movie was released, I will consider the following key points:

1. **Title and Context**: The first film in the Harry Potter series is "Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone," which was adapted from the book of the same name. The book was published in 1997, and its success led to the production of the film.

2. **Acquisition of Film Rights**: Warner Bros. acquired the film rights to the first two novels in October 1998. This acquisition is significant as it marks the beginning of the film adaptation process.

3. **Timeline of Events**: The film adaptation was released on **16 November 2001**. This release date is crucial as it follows the publication of the fourth book in July 2000, indicating that the film was produced in response to the series' growing popularity.

4. **Commercial Success**: The film grossed $90 million in its opening weekend in the United States, which set a record for worldwide openings at that time. This financial success underscores the impact of the Harry Potter franchise on the film industry.

### Causal Relationships:

cognition.content:
Fact-checking refers to the process of confirming the accuracy of a statement or claim through various sources or methods. 
This process aims to ensure that statements or claims are based on reliable and verifiable information while eliminating inaccurate or misleading content. 
Fact-checking may involve the examination of data, literature, expert opinions, or other trustworthy sources.
In the context of artificial intelligence, model illusion refers to the overconfidence response of the AI. 
When a model exhibits an 'illusion' (a tendency to output deceptive data), it indicates that the training data used by the model does not necessarily support the rationality of its outputs.
You are a scientist researching fact-checking and addressing model illusions in artificial intelligence. 
To answer the following question:
when did the first movie of harry potter come out
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['The film was released on 31 May 2004 in the United Kingdom and on 4 June 2004 in North America, as the first "Harry Potter" film released into IMAX theatres and to be using IMAX Technology. The film was nominated for two Academy Awards, Best Original Music Score and Best Visual Effects at the 77th Academy Awards in 2004.\n', 'The first trailer was released on YouTube in April 2010 and the premier was viewed by an audience of 1200 at the Europahalle theater in Trier. The film opened on 21 October 2010 at the Broadway Theater (also in Trier), becoming 7000 viewers in the first three weeks. At the time, no film in the five years preceding had sold more tickets at that theater, to include Harry Potter (film series). With an initial shipment of 5,000, the DVD was released on 9 December 2010 and by the end of January 2011 had sold 16,000 of the total 23,000 produced.\n', 'In October 1998, Warner Bros. purchased the film rights to the first two novels for a seven-figure sum. A film adaptation of "Harry Potter and the Philosopher\'s Stone" was released on 16 November 2001, and "Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets" on 15 November 2002. Both films were directed by Chris Columbus. The film version of "Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban" was released on 4 June 2004, directed by Alfonso Cuarón. The fourth film, "Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire", was directed by Mike Newell, and released on 18 November 2005. The film of "Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix" was released on 11 July 2007. David Yates directed, and Michael Goldenberg wrote the screenplay, having taken over the position from Steve Kloves. "Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince" was released on 15 July 2009. David Yates directed again, and Kloves returned to write the script. Warner Bros. filmed the final instalment of the series, "Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows", in two segments, with part one being released on 19 November 2010 and part two being released on 15 July 2011. Yates directed both films.\n', 'The rights for the first four novels in the series were sold to Warner Bros. for £1,000,000 by J.K. Rowling. After the release of the fourth book in July 2000, the first film, "Harry Potter and the Philosopher\'s Stone", was released on 16 November 2001. In its opening weekend, the film grossed $90 million in the United States alone, which set a record opening worldwide. The succeeding three motion picture adaptations followed suit in financial success, while garnering positive reviews from fans and critics. The fifth film, "Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix", was released by Warner Bros. on 11 July 2007 in English-speaking countries, except for the UK and Ireland, which released the movie on 12 July. The sixth, "Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince", was released on 15 July 2009 to critical acclaim and finished its theatrical run ranked as the number two grossing film of 2009 on the worldwide charts.\n', 'In the late 1990s, Warner obtained rights to the "Harry Potter" novels and released feature film adaptations of the first in 2001. Subsequently, they released the second film in 2002, the third in June 2004, the fourth in November 2005, the fifth in July 2007, and the sixth in July 2009. The seventh (and at that time, final) book was released as two movies; Deathly Hallows\xa0— Part 1 in November 2010 and Deathly Hallows\xa0— Part 2 in July 2011.\n', 'Although the original film release date was June 8, 2012, in January 2011 Disney moved the release date to March 9, 2012. A teaser trailer for the film premiered on July 14, 2011 and was shown in 3D and 2D with showings of "Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows – Part 2"; the official trailer premiered on November 30, 2011. On February 5, 2012 an extended commercial promoting the movie aired during the Super Bowl, and before the day of the game, Andrew Stanton, a Massachusetts native, held a special screening of the film for both the team members and families of the New England Patriots and New York Giants.\n', 'The book was published in the United Kingdom by Bloomsbury and in the United States by Scholastic; in both countries the release date was 8 July 2000, the first time a book in the series was published in both countries at the same time. The novel won a Hugo Award, the only "Harry Potter" novel to do so, in 2001. The book was adapted into a film, which was released worldwide on 18 November 2005, and a video game by Electronic Arts.\n', 'The first trailer was released on December 23, 2013 and attached theatrically with "Saving Mr. Banks". Disney heavily promoted the film through its ESPN division, with Bill Simmons being credited an executive producer on the film. The film was fully screened at CinemaCon in March 2014, wherein Walt Disney Studios chairman Alan Horn claimed that it was the highest-tested film during his tenure at either Disney or Warner Bros., including the first "Harry Potter" film. The film held its world premiere at the El Capitan Theatre on May 6, 2014.\n', 'Harold "Harry" Potts, played by Russell Dixon, made his first screen appearance on 26 October 1992.\n', 'In August 2003, British film director Mike Newell was chosen to direct the film after "Prisoner of Azkaban" director Alfonso Cuarón announced that he would not direct the sequel. Heyman returned to produce, and Kloves again wrote the screenplay. Principal photography began on 4 May 2004. Scenes involving the film\'s principal actors began shooting on 25 June 2004 at England\'s Leavesden Film Studios. "Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire" premiered on 6 November 2005 in London, and was released in the United Kingdom and the United States on 18 November. "Goblet of Fire" was the first film in the series to receive a PG-13 rating by the Motion Picture Association of America (MPAA) for "sequences of fantasy violence and frightening images," M by the Australian Classification Board (ACB), and a 12A by the British Board of Film Classification (BBFC) for its dark themes, fantasy violence, threat and frightening images.\n']

question_info.question: when did the first movie of harry potter come out
passages:
The film was released on 31 May 2004 in the United Kingdom and on 4 June 2004 in North America, as the first "Harry Potter" film released into IMAX theatres and to be using IMAX Technology. The film was nominated for two Academy Awards, Best Original Music Score and Best Visual Effects at the 77th Academy Awards in 2004.
The first trailer was released on YouTube in April 2010 and the premier was viewed by an audience of 1200 at the Europahalle theater in Trier. The film opened on 21 October 2010 at the Broadway Theater (also in Trier), becoming 7000 viewers in the first three weeks. At the time, no film in the five years preceding had sold more tickets at that theater, to include Harry Potter (film series). With an initial shipment of 5,000, the DVD was released on 9 December 2010 and by the end of January 2011 had sold 16,000 of the total 23,000 produced.
In October 1998, Warner Bros. purchased the film rights to the first two novels for a seven-figure sum. A film adaptation of "Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone" was released on 16 November 2001, and "Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets" on 15 November 2002. Both films were directed by Chris Columbus. The film version of "Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban" was released on 4 June 2004, directed by Alfonso Cuarón. The fourth film, "Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire", was directed by Mike Newell, and released on 18 November 2005. The film of "Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix" was released on 11 July 2007. David Yates directed, and Michael Goldenberg wrote the screenplay, having taken over the position from Steve Kloves. "Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince" was released on 15 July 2009. David Yates directed again, and Kloves returned to write the script. Warner Bros. filmed the final instalment of the series, "Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows", in two segments, with part one being released on 19 November 2010 and part two being released on 15 July 2011. Yates directed both films.
The rights for the first four novels in the series were sold to Warner Bros. for £1,000,000 by J.K. Rowling. After the release of the fourth book in July 2000, the first film, "Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone", was released on 16 November 2001. In its opening weekend, the film grossed $90 million in the United States alone, which set a record opening worldwide. The succeeding three motion picture adaptations followed suit in financial success, while garnering positive reviews from fans and critics. The fifth film, "Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix", was released by Warner Bros. on 11 July 2007 in English-speaking countries, except for the UK and Ireland, which released the movie on 12 July. The sixth, "Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince", was released on 15 July 2009 to critical acclaim and finished its theatrical run ranked as the number two grossing film of 2009 on the worldwide charts.
In the late 1990s, Warner obtained rights to the "Harry Potter" novels and released feature film adaptations of the first in 2001. Subsequently, they released the second film in 2002, the third in June 2004, the fourth in November 2005, the fifth in July 2007, and the sixth in July 2009. The seventh (and at that time, final) book was released as two movies; Deathly Hallows — Part 1 in November 2010 and Deathly Hallows — Part 2 in July 2011.
Although the original film release date was June 8, 2012, in January 2011 Disney moved the release date to March 9, 2012. A teaser trailer for the film premiered on July 14, 2011 and was shown in 3D and 2D with showings of "Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows – Part 2"; the official trailer premiered on November 30, 2011. On February 5, 2012 an extended commercial promoting the movie aired during the Super Bowl, and before the day of the game, Andrew Stanton, a Massachusetts native, held a special screening of the film for both the team members and families of the New England Patriots and New York Giants.
The book was published in the United Kingdom by Bloomsbury and in the United States by Scholastic; in both countries the release date was 8 July 2000, the first time a book in the series was published in both countries at the same time. The novel won a Hugo Award, the only "Harry Potter" novel to do so, in 2001. The book was adapted into a film, which was released worldwide on 18 November 2005, and a video game by Electronic Arts.
The first trailer was released on December 23, 2013 and attached theatrically with "Saving Mr. Banks". Disney heavily promoted the film through its ESPN division, with Bill Simmons being credited an executive producer on the film. The film was fully screened at CinemaCon in March 2014, wherein Walt Disney Studios chairman Alan Horn claimed that it was the highest-tested film during his tenure at either Disney or Warner Bros., including the first "Harry Potter" film. The film held its world premiere at the El Capitan Theatre on May 6, 2014.
Harold "Harry" Potts, played by Russell Dixon, made his first screen appearance on 26 October 1992.
In August 2003, British film director Mike Newell was chosen to direct the film after "Prisoner of Azkaban" director Alfonso Cuarón announced that he would not direct the sequel. Heyman returned to produce, and Kloves again wrote the screenplay. Principal photography began on 4 May 2004. Scenes involving the film's principal actors began shooting on 25 June 2004 at England's Leavesden Film Studios. "Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire" premiered on 6 November 2005 in London, and was released in the United Kingdom and the United States on 18 November. "Goblet of Fire" was the first film in the series to receive a PG-13 rating by the Motion Picture Association of America (MPAA) for "sequences of fantasy violence and frightening images," M by the Australian Classification Board (ACB), and a 12A by the British Board of Film Classification (BBFC) for its dark themes, fantasy violence, threat and frightening images.
